title: How to Write Website Content That Ranks (And People Want to Read)
description: To get traffic for your website, you'll need content that ranks on Google and engages your audience. We'll show you how to do both.
content: Si Quan Ong Content marketer @ Ahrefs. I've been in digital marketing for the past 6 years and have spoken at some of the industryâ€™s largest conferences in Asia (TIECon and Digital Marketing Skill Share.) Get the week's best marketing content Email Subscription Subscribe Leave this field empty if you're human: Contents If you want traffic coming to your website, you need website contentâ€”but not just any content.Specifically, you need website content that: Ranks on Google â€“ You need a way for people to discover your content. Googleâ€™s your best bet: 53.3% of all website traffic comes from organic search. Engages your audience â€“ Your target reader should consume your content and be compelled to take the next step, whether itâ€™s subscribing to your email list or buying your product.In this post, youâ€™ll learn how to create content that achieves both goals.Contents1. Do keyword researchYou canâ€™t get search traffic if no oneâ€™s searching for your keywords on Google. Thatâ€™s why the first step is to figure out what your target audience is searching for. This process is known as keyword research. To get started, make yourself a cup of joe, sit down, and ask yourself: â€œWhat would my target audience type in Google if they were looking for my website?â€For example, if your website sells coffee equipment, then someone may be searching for websites similar to yours using these keywords:CoffeeEspressoCappuccinoCoffee beansFrench pressWeâ€™ll then take these keywords and use them as seeds in a keyword research tool like Ahrefsâ€™ Keywords Explorer. So hereâ€™s what weâ€™ll do:Go to Keywords ExplorerEnter the keywords youâ€™ve come up with (in this example, weâ€™ll use the five coffee keywords)Go to the Matching terms reportHere, you see more than 4 million potential keywords you can target. However, not only is that too many, but most of them are also too competitive. After all, Google search doesnâ€™t exist in a vacuumâ€”if there are many websites vying for pole position, it becomes harder to rank. So we want to narrow down the results. Weâ€™ll do this using two filters:Keyword Difficulty (KD) â€“ How hard it is to rank for a particular keyword. Weâ€™ll set it to something low and manageable, around 20.Traffic Potential â€“ The potential amount of search traffic your page can get if it ranks #1. Weâ€™ll set it to 500.Itâ€™s much more manageable now. Go through the list and pick out the keywords you think are relevant to your site.Further readingKeyword Research: The Beginnerâ€™s Guide by Ahrefs 2. Create the contentWith a list of keywords to target, itâ€™s time to create content.Hereâ€™s how:Choose your content formatYour content can be a listicle, a how-to guide, an opinion piece, or more. Which one should you choose?The most straightforward way is to look at whatâ€™s ranking in Google for your chosen topic. For example, if we look at the search engine results page (SERPs) for â€œhow to save money,â€ we can see thatâ€”despite the two words â€œhow toâ€â€”people are actually looking for a list of tips.So if youâ€™re tackling this topic, your content format will likely be a listicle. This helps you compete with the existing results on the SERPs.Choose your angleYouâ€™ll want to make your content specific so your audience can clearly identify its value. This is conveyed via your contentâ€™s angle. For example, a blog post teaching how to cook fried rice fast has a clearer proposition than simply how to cook fried rice. Thereâ€™s no â€œbestâ€ or â€œcorrectâ€ angle to select, so choose one thatâ€™s novel and interesting to your readers. Here are some questions that could spark ideas:Do you have personal experience or expertise? If you have a unique fried rice recipe, share it.Can you interview experts? For example, you can interview the chef making the fried rice thatâ€™s rated 4.5* on Google.Can you crowdsource ideas? For example, you can poll people part of r/chinesecooking on their best fried rice recipes.Can you back your content with data or science? For example, you can explain how to make egg fried rice using molecular gastronomy (and explain the science behind it).Figure out important subtopics to coverYou donâ€™t want to miss out on subtopics in your postâ€”especially if itâ€™s something searchers expect to see. We can figure out what these subtopics are by looking at the common keyword rankings among the top-ranking pages:Enter your keyword (e.g., â€œinbound marketingâ€) into Ahrefsâ€™ Keywords ExplorerScroll down to the SERP overviewSelect three to five top-ranking articles (make sure theyâ€™re similar)Click Open in and choose Content gapHere, weâ€™ll want to make sure to see only the most relevant subtopics. Weâ€™ll do this by selecting the Intersection dropdown and choosing the highest two targets (in this example, 4 and 5).From here, we can see that searchers also want to know:The definition of inbound marketing.Examples of inbound marketing.Inbound marketing strategies.If weâ€™re covering the same topic (â€œinbound marketingâ€) from a similar angle (â€œbeginnerâ€™s guideâ€), then these subtopics would make good subheadings. Further readingHow to Write a Blog Post Outline (7 Simple Steps) Content Outlines: How to Write Better Content FasterDesign your content to be readableNothing is worse than having to read a chunk of text. Youâ€™ll want to make your content comfortable to read and easy on the eyes.You can do this using the ASMR formula:Annotations â€“ Add elements like sidenotes, blockquotes, and call-out boxes to break up the monotony of the post.Short sentences and paragraphs â€“ Break long sentences with lots of transitional words like â€œand,â€ â€œbecause,â€ and â€œthatâ€ into shorter ones.Multimedia â€“ Including videos, images, and GIFs helps illustrate your points without extra words.Read your copy out loud â€“ This pinpoints areas where the content doesnâ€™t flow smoothly.Write like how you talkYou donâ€™t have to puke out a word salad to impress your readers. The best online writing is friendly and casual. Treat it as if youâ€™re talking to a friend. If youâ€™re afraid your writing is too business-like, paste your draft into Hemingway:Reel your readers in with an eye-catching headlineThe famed adman David Ogilvy once said:On the average, five times as many people read the headline as read the body copy.People are busy. You need to catch their attention with the headline. So no matter how hard you work on your content, if your headline doesnâ€™t hook them, they wonâ€™t read it. The best way to come up with a good headline is volume. In other words, brainstorm as many possible headlines for your article as possible. Viral site Upworthy used to create 25 headlines for each of its articles, and bestselling author James Clear brainstormed 400 before coming up with â€œAtomic Habitsâ€:Many. I brainstormed over 400 possible titles.â€” James Clear (@JamesClear) April 13, 2020 Fortunately for you, thereâ€™s a faster way to reach this volume today. You can use ChatGPT:Donâ€™t use whatâ€™s generated verbatim, but use it to spark inspiration and help you create the perfect headline.Further readingHow to Write an Irresistible Headline in 3 Easy Steps7 Blog Title Formulas That Get Clicks (With Examples)Add your on-page SEOOn-page SEO focuses on helping Google and searchers understand and digest your content.Follow these best practices:Use the keyword in the title (if possible)Write a compelling meta description that sells your article on the SERPsAdd concise and accurate alt text to your imagesFurther readingOn-Page SEO: The Beginnerâ€™s Guide 3. Get a peer to review your workOur content is well known in the SEO industry, and weâ€™re often complimented for our content quality:Testament to the power of content marketing. You guys have one of the strongest blogs in the industryâ€” MicroSaasGuyğŸ˜ (@MicroSaasGuy) March 9, 2023 Our secret sauce? Peer review.Each writer on our team is paired with another to review each otherâ€™s work. We point out inaccuracies, logical loopholes, structural issues, spelling errors, and grammatical mistakes. We help each other improve phrasing, suggest examples, or give more ideas.This is so important to us that we even dedicate a section in the authorâ€™s box to contributors:A writer canâ€™t write aloneâ€”theyâ€™re too close to their own work. They need a third party with a fresh set of eyes to go through and provide feedback. Thatâ€™s why authors hire editorsâ€”theyâ€™re there to sharpen the prose and tighten the copy.If you have an editor to show your draft to, great. If not, you can always get the help of a friend, family member, or colleague. Even if they donâ€™t finish reading, itâ€™s still helpful because it tells you where they stopped reading. Thatâ€™s most likely the part where they lost interest, so you know where you need to improve. 4. Publish and monitor your performanceBefore you publish, run your draft through a tool like Grammarly to fix up any final grammatical, spelling, or phrasing errors.Once thatâ€™s all done, hit â€˜â€œpublish.â€Then, head over to Ahrefsâ€™ Rank Tracker and set up a project for your website.Follow through the steps. And then in step #4, add the keyword(s) youâ€™re targeting:The tool will track your websiteâ€™s ranking positions for the keywords youâ€™ve added. SEO is a continual process, and a tool like Rank Tracker will enable you to keep track of your underperforming content so you can improve it over time.Further readingContent Refreshing: A Step-by-Step Strategy (Based on Updating 50+ Posts)Republishing Content: How to Update Old Blog Posts for SEO By the way, do I have to write all the content myself?No. You can outsource.To help you decide if you should create content yourself, here are a few points to consider:Do you like writing? If you feel like vomiting every time you sit down to write a post, you should consider outsourcing.Is content creation the most important thing you can do? Iâ€™m a content marketer, so writing is my most important task. But if youâ€™re in another role, say an entrepreneur or a salesperson, then perhaps writing is not your â€œone thing.â€ It doesnâ€™t mean you shouldnâ€™t create content, but it may mean you donâ€™t do the actual writing. (Remember: Many books are written by ghostwriters.)Are you overwhelmed with tasks? If you can never find time to create content, e.g., youâ€™re a solopreneur, then itâ€™s probably better if you outsource.Are you in an industry that requires domain expertise? For some industries (e.g., health), expertise is vital not just for the sake of your readers but for ranking. If you donâ€™t have the required expertise, you may want to consider outsourcing it to someone who does. (Although you can overcome this through interviewing experts.)Do you have a budget for hiring? Time is money too, so it doesnâ€™t mean you should create all the content yourself just because you donâ€™t have a budget. Make sure itâ€™s the most important thing you can do.If youâ€™ve decided to outsource, then you can start looking for freelance writers on job boards and marketplaces. There are general ones like Upwork, and there should also be ones specific to your industry (e.g., Swipe Files is a job board for marketers).Further readingHow to Hire Freelance Writers in 5 Steps (Ahrefsâ€™ Process) Final thoughtsIf you follow through the steps above, youâ€™ll create content that Google loves.
